Students learn how to identify customer needs, present solutions, manage accounts, and develop strong relationships. Graduates will have the knowledge and skills necessary to be successful in a variety of sales and sales management positions in business-to-business and business-to-consumer settings across various industries. Students gain an understanding of sales strategies, sales operations, and sales leadership. An emphasis is placed on developing professional selling skills, ethical decision making, and the use of technology in sales. In addition, students complete an internship to gain real-world experience.
Program name: Bachelor of Business Administration in Sales Management
Bachelor of Fine Arts in Sculpture

description: At The University of Akron, the Bachelor of Arts in Social Work (BASW) program prepares students for beginning professional social work practice in a variety of settings. Students will acquire the generalist knowledge, skills, and values to work with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities. The curriculum emphasizes social justice, diversity, and evidence-based practice within a strengths-based, ecological framework. Graduates are prepared for direct service roles, advocacy, community engagement, and further education in social work.
Accreditation status: The BASW program is fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Social Work

description: The B.S. in Chemistry with Polymer Option is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in the core chemistry disciplines in addition to a substantial background in polymer science. The curriculum includes course work in organic chemistry, inorganic chemistry, analytical chemistry, physical chemistry, biochemistry and polymer chemistry. Students are required to complete a minimum of 13 credit hours of polymer-related courses. Students are also required to complete a 3-credit hour research experience or co-op experience. All students in this program are encouraged to engage in undergraduate research with a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry or the School of Polymer Science and Polymer Engineering. The Polymer Option is an excellent choice for students interested in graduate studies in polymer science and engineering or for students interested in working in the polymer industry.
Accreditation status: Approved by the American Chemical Society (ACS).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Chemistry with a Polymer Option
Bachelor of Science in Mild/Moderate Intervention Specialist (Grades K - 12)

description: The Bachelor of Science in Intervention Specialist (K-12) prepares students to teach individuals with moderate/intensive needs in grades K-12. The program also leads to eligibility for the Ohio moderate/intensive intervention specialist teaching license. The program integrates general education and specialized instruction in pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, technology, classroom management, and professional collaboration to maximize learning for students with disabilities. This program prepares candidates to work with students who have moderate to intensive learning and/or behavioral disabilities. Throughout the program, you will learn to implement evidence-based practices for academic, social-emotional, and behavioral instruction, manage a classroom with diverse learners, and collaborate with families and other professionals. In addition to a comprehensive curriculum, the program offers extensive fieldwork experiences, including diverse classroom settings and a full-time student teaching experience.
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in education at The University of Akron is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). The University of Akron’s professional education programs are approved by the Ohio Department of Higher Education (ODHE).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Moderate/Intensive Intervention Specialist (Grades K - 12)

description: The Early Childhood Intervention Specialist program leads to a Bachelor of Science degree in Education and an Ohio teaching license for Early Childhood Intervention Specialist (Age 3 – Grade 3). It prepares teachers of young children with disabilities in a variety of educational settings. The program provides a foundation in theories of child development and learning, curriculum methods, assessment, teaching strategies, working with families and other professionals, and legal issues. Students complete extensive field experience, including student teaching, in diverse settings.
Accreditation status: Approved by the Ohio Department of Higher Education (ODHE) and accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Early Childhood Intervention Specialist (Age 3 - Grade 3)

description: The University of Akron's Bachelor of Arts in History/Juris Doctor 3+3 program allows high-achieving undergraduate students to earn both their bachelor's and law degrees in just six years, rather than the traditional seven. This program is an excellent opportunity for students who are committed to pursuing a career in law. You will gain a strong foundation in history, critical thinking, research, and writing skills, all of which are essential for success in law school and beyond. The 3+3 program not only saves you a year of tuition and living expenses but also accelerates your entry into the legal profession. Upon completion of the three-year undergraduate portion of the program, you will matriculate to the School of Law, where your first year of law school credits will count towards both your bachelor's degree and your Juris Doctor.
Accreditation status: The University of Akron and all of its programs are accredited by the Higher Learning Commission.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in History/Law 3+3

description: The Philosophy/Law 3+3 program allows high-achieving undergraduate students to earn a Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy and a Juris Doctor (JD) degree in six years. Students complete their undergraduate studies in three years (90 credits) and then matriculate to the School of Law. Upon successful completion of their first year in the School of Law (30 credits), the JD credits are applied toward the Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy. Students then complete their remaining two years of law school to earn the Juris Doctor degree. This accelerates the process of earning both degrees by one year, saving time and tuition expenses.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy/Law 3+3

description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Political Science/National Security is a multidisciplinary program offered by the Department of Political Science. It addresses the growing need for a national security workforce capable of addressing the complex challenges facing the United States in the 21st century. The program is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in political science, international relations, and security studies, preparing them for careers in government, intelligence, defense, and international organizations. Students will develop critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills essential for understanding and responding to national security threats and challenges.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science/National Security

description: Earn your bachelor's degree in political science and your Juris Doctor (J.D.) in only six years instead of seven with this joint accelerated program. As a part of this program, you will gain hands-on experience through internships and mock trials to give you a strong foundation for your future career. You will learn skills in critical thinking, writing, and analysis to help you become a successful attorney. We also offer a 4+3 program that allows you to earn both degrees in seven years, where you will complete your undergraduate degree in four years and your J.D. in three.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Political Science/Law 3+3

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Political Science, and Economics (PPE) provides students with a multidisciplinary understanding of these three intertwined fields. This degree is designed to give students a comprehensive liberal arts education that focuses on critical thinking, ethical reasoning, and analytical skills. The program prepares students for a wide range of careers in law, public service, business, and non-profit organizations, as well as for advanced studies in law, public policy, or academic fields. The PPE program offers: A broad foundation in philosophical thought, political systems, and economic principles. The ability to analyze complex social, political, and economic issues from multiple perspectives. Strong skills in critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making. Preparation for leadership roles in various sectors. Opportunities for internships, research, and study abroad experiences.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Political Science, and Economics

description:
The B.A. in Philosophy, Sociology and Psychology is a uniquely interdisciplinary program focused on the study of human beings and the ways in which individuals and groups interact in a diverse and complex world. This program provides students with a broad and rigorous exposure to the foundational theories and methods within the fields of Philosophy, Sociology, and Psychology, helping them to develop critical thinking, communication, and research skills applicable to a wide variety of careers and post-graduate study.
Students in the program examine topics such as:
*   Ethics, values, and morality
*   Social justice and inequality
*   Human behavior and cognition
*   Cultural diversity
*   Critical reasoning and argumentation
The interdisciplinary nature of the program encourages students to analyze complex problems from multiple perspectives, fostering a holistic understanding of societal challenges and human experience. Graduates are prepared for careers in fields such as social work, counseling, education, public policy, human resources, law, and research, or for advanced studies in any of the three disciplines or related interdisciplinary fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy, Sociology and Psychology

description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) degree in sociology provides you with the intellectual tools to understand the social world. Sociology is the scientific study of human society and social behavior. Sociologists examine the organization of social groups, institutions, and societies; patterns of social inequality; the causes and consequences of social change; and the relationships between individuals and society. The sociology major at UA emphasizes critical thinking, scientific inquiry, and social justice. Sociology majors learn to think critically about society, conduct research, and analyze data using both qualitative and quantitative methods. A B.A. in sociology also provides an excellent liberal arts background for students planning on pursuing graduate or professional training in law, social work, business, public administration, or other fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Sociology

description:
PROGRAM GOALS: Provide students with a solid foundation in the Spanish language. Familiarize students with the cultural, social, and political contexts of Spanish-speaking peoples. Help students develop an understanding of literary traditions and critical approaches to Hispanic literatures. Foster students' critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills. Prepare students for careers in diverse fields that require proficiency in Spanish and cultural competence. Cultivate in students an appreciation for global citizenship and intercultural understanding.

STUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES: Students will demonstrate advanced proficiency in oral and written communication in Spanish. Students will analyze and interpret literary and cultural texts in Spanish. Students will evaluate the social, political, and historical contexts of Spanish-speaking communities. Students will apply critical thinking skills to current events and global issues concerning the Hispanic world. Students will articulate the relevance of Spanish language and culture in a globalized world.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Spanish

description:
Corrosion is the destructive attack of a metal by reaction with its environment. It affects almost every industry, causing significant economic losses, safety issues and environmental damage. Corrosion engineers are critical in understanding, preventing and controlling corrosion to extend the life of materials, ensuring safety and minimizing costs in many fields including infrastructure, biomedical, aerospace, oil and gas, manufacturing, and defense.

The University of Akron’s Bachelor of Science in Corrosion Engineering program is the first and only one of its kind in the United States. Our graduates are highly sought after by industry, government and graduate schools. Students in the program develop a strong background in materials science, electrochemistry and corrosion control engineering principles. The program emphasizes hands-on experience, with students participating in co-op work experiences, undergraduate research, and laboratory-intensive courses.

Our graduates are prepared to address real-world corrosion challenges by applying engineering principles to design, evaluate and implement corrosion prevention and control strategies. They gain expertise in:

*   Understanding the fundamentals of corrosion mechanisms and material degradation processes.
*   Designing and implementing corrosion control strategies, including material selection, protective coatings, cathodic protection, and inhibitors.
*   Utilizing advanced analytical techniques to diagnose corrosion problems and assess material performance.
*   Applying economic and environmental considerations in corrosion engineering solutions.
*   Collaborating effectively in multidisciplinary teams to solve complex engineering challenges.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Corrosion Engineering

description: The minor in Business Data Analytics (BDA) prepares students with fundamental knowledge and skills in data analytics that are applicable to most fields of business and management. By working with real-world data, students develop valuable skills in collecting, processing, analyzing and interpreting large data sets with the goal of making better, more informed business decisions. Skills include data visualization, statistical analysis, database management, and more.
Program name: Minor in Business Data Analytics

description: The minor in economics is designed for students of any major who want to develop a deeper understanding of current economic issues without committing to a full major. Understanding economics helps students make better decisions in their personal, professional, and civic lives. It provides a solid analytical framework for a wide array of career options, including law, business, journalism, public policy, healthcare, and foreign service. It also provides excellent preparation for graduate study in business, law, and other fields.
Program name: Minor in Economics

description: The Leadership and Human Resources minor is designed to help students acquire a foundation of knowledge and skills in organizational behavior and human resource management (HRM). Students will learn about topics such as motivation, teamwork, leadership, training and development, performance management, and compensation. This minor is an excellent complement to many majors across campus.
Program name: Minor in Leadership and Human Resources

Accreditation status: Accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB).
Program name: Minor in Information Systems Management

description: Risk is a part of our personal and professional lives. Risk management and insurance professionals analyze, measure and treat risks. Their job is to protect people and organizations from financial losses stemming from property, casualty, liability, and other risks. They protect assets such as homes, cars, businesses and even lives. The risk management and insurance minor prepares students to analyze and evaluate risk, assess risk financing options, and implement risk solutions. Graduates are prepared for careers in risk management and insurance. Students are prepared to take the AIDA and AINS exams.
Accreditation status: The College of Business at The University of Akron is accredited by AACSB International, the premier accrediting agency for business schools worldwide.
Program name: Minor in Risk Management and Insurance

description:
Enhance your business education by adding a minor in Supply Chain/Operations Management. This minor will give you a fundamental understanding of critical business functions such as purchasing, logistics, inventory management and operations planning. Graduates with this minor will acquire the skills needed to manage the flow of goods and services from suppliers to customers.
What You'll Learn
* Recognize and apply best practices in purchasing, logistics, inventory management, production and process improvement.
* Understand the strategic importance of operations and supply chain management within an organization.
* Develop analytical and problem-solving skills for effective decision-making in operations and supply chain management environments.
Accreditation status: AACSB International – the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB) accreditation for the College of Business Administration.
Program name: Minor in Supply Chain/Operations Management
Bachelor of Science in Applied AI & Information Systems

description: Students pursuing the Associate of Arts in Communication Option are exposed to a broad knowledge of communication theory and practice. The program helps students develop a foundational knowledge of communication, strengthen analytical and critical thinking, and foster an appreciation for diverse cultures and backgrounds. The curriculum prepares students for entry-level positions in communication-related fields or transfer to a bachelor's degree program.
Program name: Associate of Arts in Communication Option

description: The Humanities Divisional Major is for students who want to develop their own interdisciplinary major in the Humanities, focusing on topics, periods, or areas of interest that do not fit into traditional departmental majors. To declare the Humanities Divisional major, students must consult with the chair of the Department of Philosophy to design a proposal for their program. The Divisional Major in Humanities consists of 30 credits above the 100-level approved by the chair of the Department of Philosophy, with no more than 15 credits from any one department. For additional information, contact the Department of Philosophy at 330-972-7078.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Humanities Divisional

description: The Associate of Science in Construction Management (ASCM) provides students with the foundational knowledge and skills required for careers in the construction industry. This program focuses on project management, construction methods, cost estimating, safety, and sustainable building practices. Graduates are prepared for entry-level positions in residential, commercial, and industrial construction, or for seamless transfer into a related bachelor's degree program. The University of Akron's ASCM program stands out due to its hands-on learning approach, experienced faculty, and strong industry connections. Students benefit from practical training through labs, site visits, and internship opportunities, ensuring they gain real-world experience. Our curriculum is regularly updated to reflect current industry trends and technologies, providing graduates with a competitive edge.
Program name: Associate of Science in Construction Management Option

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with a Divisional PPE Track (Philosophy, Politics, and Economics) is an interdisciplinary program focusing on the intersection of these three critical areas. This track provides students with a robust understanding of social, political, and economic systems, emphasizing critical thinking, analytical reasoning, and ethical decision-making. Students explore fundamental questions related to justice, governance, markets, and human behavior through a comprehensive curriculum that integrates perspectives from philosophy, political science, and economics. This rigorous program prepares graduates for diverse careers in public service, law, business, non-profit organizations, and advanced academic pursuits by developing strong communication skills, problem-solving abilities, and a global perspective.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences, Divisional PPE Track

description: This interdisciplinary major is designed for students with strong academic records who are interested in pursuing graduate or professional education. The Divisional PSP (Pre-Service Preparation) Track is a challenging major tailored for students who intend to enter a professional Master’s program (such as law, social work, public administration, public policy, or business) or a doctoral program (such as in economics, political science, sociology, psychology, or history). The Divisional PSP Track is housed within the Buchtel College of Arts and Sciences in Interdisciplinary Programs. Its students receive intensive advising, take courses that encourage critical thinking, quantitative literacy, and analytical abilities, complete a capstone seminar, and participate in an internship or research experience.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences, Divisional PSP Track

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with a divisional major is designed for students interested in a broad-based education covering multiple areas within the social sciences, rather than focusing on a single discipline. This program offers a flexible curriculum that allows students to explore various fields such as anthropology, economics, political science, sociology, and psychology. Students gain a comprehensive understanding of human behavior, societal structures, and cultural dynamics, preparing them for a wide range of careers or further graduate studies. This program stands out for its interdisciplinary approach, fostering critical thinking, analytical skills, and a global perspective. Students benefit from the expertise of faculty across multiple departments, engaging in diverse topics and research methodologies. The flexibility of the divisional major allows students to tailor their coursework to their interests, creating a personalized academic journey. Graduates are well-equipped for roles in government, non-profit organizations, research, education, and various private sector industries requiring strong analytical and communication skills.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences, Divisional

description: This accelerated baccalaureate degree program is designed for individuals who hold a bachelor's degree in another field and want to become a registered nurse. This fast-paced program provides students with the opportunity to complete the BSN in 12 months in a full-time, rigorous, face-to-face format. Students are admitted once a year in May and follow a prescribed course of study designed to lead to successful completion of the NCLEX-RN and entry into professional nursing practice. Graduates are prepared for leadership roles, graduate study, and a variety of practice settings within the healthcare system.
Accreditation status: The School of Nursing offers degree programs accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (Accelerated)
Bachelor of Science in Nursing (for LPNs)

description: The online RN to BSN program at The University of Akron is designed for registered nurses who have an associate degree in nursing or a hospital diploma and want to earn their Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) degree. The program provides the knowledge and skills necessary for the professional nurse to meet the health care needs of diverse populations. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, leadership, evidence-based practice, and community health. The RN to BSN program is taught by experienced faculty who are dedicated to helping students succeed. The program is flexible and can be completed at a pace that fits your busy schedule. Courses are offered online, allowing you to learn from anywhere, anytime.
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing at The University of Akron is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (RN to BSN)
